depth_guidance.deep: Comprehensive functional analysis: every chain classified with multi-layered function assessment, diachronic function tracking (how argumentative role changed over the author's career), assessment of whether the author is aware of each chain's actual function, and comparison of stated vs actual argumentative roles
depth_guidance.standard: Full classification of all significant chains with primary and secondary functions, textual evidence, function-shift tracking across works, and confidence ratings
depth_guidance.surface: Classify the 5-7 most significant chains with brief functional labels and one-line evidence

analytical_dimensions.description: Classifying each significant conceptual chain by its argumentative function. A chain may serve multiple functions across different works or even within a single work. The five primary functions are: foundational (establishing premises, grounding the argument), elaborative (developing implications, extending scope, adding detail), defensive (responding to objections, shoring up vulnerabilities), bridge (connecting otherwise separate domains or sub-arguments), and culminative (drawing conclusions, reaching endpoints of argumentative arcs). Each classification must cite specific textual evidence for the assigned function.
probing_questions: For each conceptual chain, what argumentative job does it primarily do?
Does the chain serve different functions in different works or contexts?
What textual evidence supports this functional classification?
Are there chains whose function is ambiguous or contested?
Has the chain's argumentative function shifted over the author's career?

depth_guidance.deep: Complete architectural analysis: full dependency graph, structural logic classification, diachronic architecture evolution, comparison of the author's explicit argument structure with the implicit architecture revealed by functional analysis, and identification of where the architecture is most elegant and where it is most kludgy
depth_guidance.standard: Map the full argumentative architecture showing dependencies, hierarchies, bottlenecks, and structural logic across the corpus
depth_guidance.surface: Sketch the main architectural connections between the 3-5 most important chains

analytical_dimensions.description: How the functionally classified chains compose into larger argumentative structures. This is the macroscopic view -- not just what each chain does, but how they fit together. Which foundational chains support which elaborative chains? Which defensive chains protect which claims? Which bridges enable which connections? The architecture reveals the argument's engineering: its hierarchies, its bottlenecks, its redundancies, and its overall structural logic.
probing_questions: How do foundational chains connect to the elaborative and culminative chains they support?
What is the hierarchical structure -- which chains depend on which?
Are there bottleneck chains where the entire argument flows through a single point?
What is the overall structural logic -- linear, branching, converging, cyclic?
How does the architecture change between the author's earlier and later works?

depth_guidance.deep: Complete structural engineering analysis: load distribution map, stress testing (what happens if each load-bearing chain is weakened), support deficit identification (where critical chains lack adequate backing), comparison of the author's perceived vs actual load-bearing structure, and recommendations for structural reinforcement
depth_guidance.standard: Full load analysis: all load-bearing chains ranked by structural importance, support proportionality assessment, single points of failure, and prominence vs importance comparison
depth_guidance.surface: Identify the 2-3 most structurally critical chains and note their support level

analytical_dimensions.description: Which conceptual chains are structurally essential -- if removed, the argument collapses? Load-bearing chains may not be the most prominent or the most discussed; sometimes the most critical structural member is an unexamined assumption or a quiet bridge concept. This analysis identifies which chains carry the most argumentative weight and assesses whether that weight is proportional to the evidential support they receive.
probing_questions: Which chains, if removed, would cause the most structural damage to the argument?
Is the load distribution proportional -- do heavily loaded chains receive proportional support?
Are there load-bearing chains that the author treats as obvious or uncontroversial?
What is the relationship between a chain's prominence in the text and its structural importance?
Are there single points of failure -- chains where the entire argument depends on one contested premise?

depth_guidance.deep: Full redundancy audit: complete overlap map, intentionality assessment for each redundancy, resilience analysis (how the argument survives if redundant chains are removed), historical redundancy trajectory, and comparison with what an optimal argumentative architecture would look like
depth_guidance.standard: Map all significant redundancies and gaps, assess intentionality, and compare redundancy levels across argumentative functions
depth_guidance.surface: Note the most obvious redundancies and single-thread dependencies

analytical_dimensions.description: Where do multiple conceptual chains do the same argumentative work? Redundancy is not necessarily a flaw -- in engineering, redundancy provides resilience. But in argumentation, unintended redundancy may indicate confusion, while intentional redundancy may indicate strategic reinforcement. This dimension maps overlapping argumentative functions and assesses whether the redundancy is productive (providing alternative routes to the same conclusion) or wasteful (repeating the same work without adding value).
probing_questions: Which chains perform overlapping argumentative functions?
Is the redundancy intentional (strategic reinforcement) or accidental (conceptual confusion)?
Does the redundancy add resilience or just complexity?
Are there argumentative functions that have NO redundancy -- single-thread dependencies?
Has redundancy increased or decreased across the author's career?

depth_guidance.deep: Complete vulnerability assessment: all weak points mapped with severity and exploitability ratings, simulated adversarial attacks, recommendations for structural reinforcement, comparison of vulnerabilities across the author's career (are they getting better or worse at structural defense?), and assessment of whether some vulnerabilities are productive (enabling flexibility) vs dangerous (threatening collapse)
depth_guidance.standard: Map all significant vulnerabilities with severity ratings, attack vectors, and assessment of how the author could address them

analytical_dimensions.description: Where is the argument weakest? This synthesizes the load-bearing analysis and redundancy map to identify the points of maximum vulnerability. An argument is vulnerable where: load-bearing chains lack adequate support, single-thread dependencies have no redundancy, defensive chains are weak or absent where they are most needed, and bridge concepts do unacknowledged heavy lifting. The vulnerability assessment is not a hostile critique but a structural diagnosis -- understanding where an argument is vulnerable is the first step toward strengthening it.
probing_questions: Where does the argument have the least structural support for the most critical claims?
Which defensive chains are weakest relative to the objections they face?
Where are bridge concepts doing unacknowledged heavy lifting?
What are the most likely points of failure under critical examination?
How would a sophisticated interlocutor attack this argument, and where would it break?

depth_scaling.deep: Exhaustive multi-layered functional analysis including stated vs. actual functions, authorial awareness assessment, function evolution across career, ambiguous cases adjudicated, and comparison of functional architecture across different periods
depth_scaling.standard: Complete functional classification of all significant chains including primary and secondary functions, confidence ratings, diachronic function tracking, and detailed textual evidence
depth_scaling.surface: Primary function labels for 5-7 major chains with one-line textual evidence for each classification

capabilities.description: Assign foundational/elaborative/defensive/bridge/culminative functions to each conceptual chain with textual evidence
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability performs the foundational work of identifying what argumentative job each conceptual chain actually does within the author's corpus. Drawing on Toulmin's insight that arguments have internal structure—not just claims but warrants, backing, qualifiers, and rebuttals—it moves beyond content analysis to functional analysis. A concept may appear to be about epistemology, but argumentatively it functions as a warrant for an ethical claim; another may seem central thematically but actually plays a defensive role, shoring up a vulnerability the author barely acknowledges. The classification into five functions (foundational, elaborative, defensive, bridge, culminative) is not taxonomic pedantry but structural diagnosis: it reveals what each conceptual element is actually doing in the argument's architecture.

This capability provides the essential input for all downstream analyses. Without functional classification, we cannot map argumentative architecture (which requires knowing what each chain does), identify load-bearing elements (since load depends on function), detect redundancy (overlapping functions), or assess vulnerabilities (weak chains in critical functional roles). It transforms concept_synthesis's diachronic account of conceptual evolution into a synchronic picture of argumentative structure. The non-trivial dimension is recognizing when a chain's actual function diverges from its apparent function—when an author treats something as elaborative that is actually load-bearing, or when a defensive move is disguised as neutral elaboration.
indicators: Conceptual chains that appear repeatedly at the beginning of argumentative sequences, establishing premises for subsequent moves
Chains that emerge primarily in contexts where the author is responding to critics or anticipating objections
Concepts that connect otherwise disparate domains or sub-arguments, enabling the author to move between them
Chains that appear at the culmination of argumentative arcs, drawing together previously separate threads
Divergence between how prominently a concept is discussed and how much argumentative weight it actually bears

intellectual_grounding.method: Toulmin's layout of arguments distinguishes data, claim, warrant, backing, qualifier, and rebuttal—each playing a specific structural role. This capability applies that functional differentiation to conceptual chains, asking not 'what does this chain mean?' but 'what argumentative work does it do?'—whether it grounds (foundational), extends (elaborative), connects (bridge), protects (defensive), or concludes (culminative).

depth_scaling.deep: Comprehensive architectural analysis including full inferential network, diachronic evolution of structure, explicit vs. implicit architecture comparison, elegance assessment, and identification of structural kludges where the argument is held together awkwardly
depth_scaling.standard: Complete dependency graph showing hierarchies, bottlenecks, structural logic classification, and flow patterns across the full corpus
depth_scaling.surface: Sketch showing how 3-5 major chains connect, identifying whether the overall structure is primarily linear, branching, or converging

capabilities.description: Compose functionally classified chains into macroscopic argumentative structures showing hierarchies and dependencies
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability constructs the macroscopic view of how functionally classified chains compose into larger argumentative structures. It answers the question: how does the argument hold together? Drawing on structural analysis traditions, it treats the argument as an engineered object with hierarchies, dependencies, and flow patterns. Which foundational chains support which elaborative developments? Where do defensive chains protect load-bearing claims? How do bridge concepts enable otherwise impossible connections? The architecture reveals whether the argument is linear (each step following sequentially), branching (multiple independent lines from common premises), converging (separate arguments leading to unified conclusions), or cyclic (concepts that mutually reinforce in loops).

This capability depends on functional_classification but transcends it: knowing what each chain does is necessary but not sufficient for understanding how they compose. A foundational chain only matters structurally if other chains actually depend on it; a bridge concept only functions architecturally if it genuinely connects domains that would otherwise be separate. The mapping reveals bottlenecks (single chains through which the entire argument flows), redundant pathways (multiple routes to the same conclusion), and structural elegance or awkwardness. The non-trivial aspect is distinguishing the author's explicit argument structure (how they say their argument proceeds) from the implicit architecture (how the conceptual chains actually relate). Often these diverge significantly—an author may present a linear argument whose actual structure is radically branching, or claim independence for sub-arguments that share hidden dependencies.
indicators: Explicit statements of argumentative dependency ('as we established in...', 'this rests on...', 'from this it follows that...')
Conceptual chains that only appear after other specific chains have been established, suggesting hierarchical dependency
Passages where multiple previously separate argumentative lines converge onto a single claim
Moments where the argument appears to loop back, with later developments reinforcing or reinterpreting earlier foundations
Transitions between domains or registers that require specific bridge concepts to accomplish

intellectual_grounding.method: Brandom's account of concepts as nodes in inferential networks—individuated by their role in reasoning, their position in the 'space of reasons'—informs this architectural mapping. Each conceptual chain's argumentative identity depends on its inferential relations to others: what it supports, what supports it, what it enables, what it blocks. The architecture is the made-explicit inferential network.

depth_scaling.deep: Full structural engineering analysis including load distribution mapping, stress testing for each chain, support deficit quantification, authorial awareness comparison (perceived vs. actual load-bearers), and specific recommendations for structural reinforcement where load exceeds support
depth_scaling.standard: Complete ranking of load-bearing chains by structural importance, proportionality assessment for each, single-point-of-failure identification, and comparison of prominence versus actual load
depth_scaling.surface: Identification of 2-3 most critical chains with brief assessment of whether their support level matches their structural importance

capabilities.description: Identify structurally essential chains and assess whether their load is proportional to their support
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability identifies which conceptual chains are structurally essential—if removed or significantly weakened, the argument collapses or requires major restructuring. Load-bearing analysis treats the argument as an engineering problem: which elements carry weight, how much weight, and whether the support is proportional to the load? A chain bears load when other significant argumentative moves depend on it, either as foundation (supporting subsequent claims), as warrant (licensing inferential moves), or as bridge (enabling connections). The critical insight is that load-bearing status is not the same as prominence: sometimes the most structurally essential claims are treated as obvious background assumptions, while heavily discussed concepts may turn out to be ornamental.

This capability requires both functional_classification (to know what each chain does) and argumentative_architecture (to see what depends on what). It produces a ranking of structural importance that often surprises: the chain doing the most work may not be the one receiving the most attention. The analysis also assesses proportionality—whether heavily loaded chains receive adequate backing and defense. A load-bearing chain supported only by assertion or thin evidence is a structural vulnerability. The non-trivial dimension is recognizing hidden load-bearers: chains that appear only briefly, are treated as uncontroversial, or are never explicitly defended, yet turn out to be indispensable. Often these are methodological assumptions, meta-level commitments, or bridge concepts whose removal would disconnect entire domains of the argument.
indicators: Conceptual chains that are referenced or presupposed by many other argumentative moves without being extensively defended
Chains whose removal would require the author to substantially restructure multiple other arguments
Concepts treated as obvious or uncontroversial that nevertheless enable significant inferential moves
Single chains that appear in multiple argumentative contexts, doing different but essential work in each
Disproportionate attention patterns: either extensive discussion of structurally minor points or passing treatment of structurally essential ones

intellectual_grounding.method: Toulmin distinguishes warrants (inference licenses) from backing (support for warrants): warrants bear argumentative load by enabling inferential moves, but they themselves require backing proportional to their load. This capability extends that insight: it identifies which conceptual chains function as load-bearing warrants and assesses whether their backing is adequate to the weight they carry—whether support is proportional to structural importance.

depth_scaling.deep: Exhaustive redundancy audit including complete overlap map, genuine vs. pseudo-redundancy distinction, resilience testing (argument survival if redundant chains removed), historical trajectory of redundancy patterns across career, and normative comparison with optimal redundancy architecture
depth_scaling.standard: Complete overlap mapping showing all significant redundancies, intentionality assessment for each, resilience analysis, and comparison of redundancy levels across different argumentative functions
depth_scaling.surface: Identification of most obvious redundancies and single-thread dependencies with brief assessment of whether redundancy seems intentional

capabilities.description: Detect overlapping argumentative functions and assess whether redundancy is productive or wasteful
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability detects where multiple conceptual chains perform overlapping or identical argumentative functions. In structural engineering, redundancy is a virtue—it provides resilience, alternative load paths when one element fails. But argumentative redundancy is ambiguous: it can be strategic reinforcement (multiple independent routes to the same conclusion, strengthening the argument's resilience) or conceptual confusion (the same work repeated without recognition, adding complexity without value). This capability maps functional overlaps and assesses their character. Productive redundancy offers genuinely independent paths—if one chain is challenged, others remain intact. Wasteful redundancy merely restates the same move in different vocabulary, creating the illusion of multiple supports while actually depending on the same premises.

This analysis complements load_bearing_analysis: where that capability identifies critical single points of failure, this one identifies areas of structural resilience (multiple chains doing the same work) and areas of conceptual profligacy (unnecessary duplication). The mapping also reveals gaps—argumentative functions with no redundancy, where the entire argument depends on a single chain with no backup. The non-trivial dimension is distinguishing genuine redundancy (truly independent alternative paths) from pseudo-redundancy (apparent alternatives that secretly depend on the same premises or that differ only superficially). It requires tracking whether redundant chains have independent evidential bases, whether they appeal to different warrants, and whether they could survive independent challenges.
indicators: Multiple conceptual chains that appear in similar argumentative contexts, doing similar work
Different terminology or frameworks used to reach identical or near-identical conclusions
Passages where the author seems to restart an argument rather than building linearly on previous work
Explicitly acknowledged alternative paths ('another way to see this...', 'independently, we can argue...')
Critical argumentative moves that have only a single supporting chain with no alternative routes

intellectual_grounding.method: Perelman's new rhetoric emphasizes that arguments gain strength through multiple independent lines of reasoning—redundancy of argumentation schemes provides resilience. This capability applies that insight: it identifies where authors deploy multiple argumentative strategies for the same claim and assesses whether the redundancy genuinely diversifies the argument's support (strategic) or merely repeats the same move (wasteful).

depth_scaling.deep: Comprehensive adversarial analysis including full vulnerability catalogue with severity and exploitability ratings, simulated attacks by sophisticated critics, specific structural reinforcement recommendations, diachronic comparison of vulnerability patterns across career, and distinction between dangerous vulnerabilities (threatening collapse) and productive vulnerabilities (enabling flexibility)
depth_scaling.standard: Complete vulnerability mapping with severity ratings, attack vectors, exploitation assessment, and recommendations for how the author could strengthen weak points
depth_scaling.surface: Identification of 2-3 most significant vulnerabilities with brief severity assessment

capabilities.description: Synthesize load and redundancy analyses to identify points of maximum argumentative vulnerability
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability synthesizes load_bearing_analysis and redundancy_map to diagnose the argument's structural weaknesses—points where it is most susceptible to collapse under critical pressure. An argument is vulnerable where: essential load-bearing chains lack adequate support (high load, low backing), critical functions depend on single chains with no redundancy (single points of failure), defensive chains are weak or absent where objections are strongest, and bridge concepts do unacknowledged heavy lifting (connections that seem obvious but rest on contested premises). This is not hostile critique but structural diagnosis: making vulnerabilities visible is the first step toward understanding and potentially strengthening them.

The assessment goes beyond identifying weak points to evaluating their severity and exploitability. A vulnerability is severe if its failure cascades—weakening one chain undermines many others. It is exploitable if a sophisticated interlocutor could readily identify and attack it. The capability simulates adversarial engagement: how would a knowledgeable critic approach this argument? Where would they apply pressure? What would break first? This requires understanding not just the argument's internal structure but also the broader dialectical context—what objections exist in the literature, what premises are contested, what moves are controversial. The non-trivial dimension is distinguishing dangerous vulnerabilities (points where the argument genuinely risks collapse) from productive vulnerabilities (points of flexibility where the argument can accommodate revision without losing its core).
indicators: Load-bearing chains with minimal textual support or defense, treated as obvious when they are actually controversial
Single chains connecting entire domains with no alternative bridges, where the connection rests on contested premises
Defensive chains that respond to objections but remain weak relative to the strength of those objections
Cascading dependencies where weakening one chain would undermine multiple downstream arguments
Gaps in argumentation where expected defensive moves are absent or where known objections go unaddressed

intellectual_grounding.method: Walton's approach to argumentation schemes includes 'critical questions'—standard challenges that test each scheme's application. This capability extends that dialectical method to entire argumentative architectures: it identifies where critical questions would be most damaging, where the argument lacks resources to answer them, and where structural weaknesses make the argument exploitable by sophisticated critics.

consumes_from.concept_synthesis: Evolution timelines, semantic cores, convergence/divergence maps, and aggregated traces from the synthesis engine
consumes_from.conceptual_framework_extraction: From Pass 1 -- vocabulary and methodology profile providing the raw conceptual material
consumes_from.inferential_commitment_mapper: From Pass 1 -- explicit and implicit commitments forming the logical skeleton

shares_with.argumentative_architecture: Macroscopic argument structure showing how chains compose
shares_with.functional_classifications: Per-chain argumentative function labels with evidence, available for downstream engines
shares_with.load_bearing_chains: Structurally essential chains ranked by importance
shares_with.vulnerability_map: Points of structural weakness with severity and exploitability ratings

depth_levels.description: Classify the most significant chains and sketch the main architectural connections

passes.description:
A single pass to classify the 5-7 most significant conceptual
chains by their argumentative function (foundational, elaborative,
defensive, bridge, culminative) and sketch the main architectural
connections between them. Note the most obvious load-bearing
chains, any visible redundancies, and the most apparent
vulnerabilities. The goal is a structural sketch sufficient
for preliminary assessment, not a complete engineering analysis.
passes.label: Functional Classification Scan

depth_levels.suitable_for: Quick structural overview, policy documents, preliminary assessment of argument structure

depth_levels.description: Full functional classification of all significant chains, complete architectural mapping, load-bearing analysis, redundancy mapping, and vulnerability assessment

passes.description:
Systematic classification of all significant conceptual chains
by their argumentative function. For each chain, assign primary
and secondary functions with textual evidence. Track whether
the chain's function shifts across different works or contexts.
Note chains whose function is ambiguous or contested. Assess
confidence in each classification. This pass produces the
functional inventory that architectural analysis requires --
you cannot map the architecture until you know what each
component does.
passes.label: Complete Functional Classification

passes.description:
With functional classifications in hand, build the complete
argumentative architecture. Map how chains compose: which
foundational chains support which elaborative chains, which
defensive chains protect which claims, which bridges enable
which connections. Identify load-bearing chains and assess
whether their structural importance is proportional to their
evidential support. Map redundancies and single-thread
dependencies. Synthesize load and redundancy analyses into a
vulnerability assessment: where is the argument weakest, and
what are the most likely points of failure under critical
examination?
passes.label: Architectural and Structural Analysis

depth_levels.suitable_for: Most academic texts, standard genealogy analysis, peer review preparation, structural critique

depth_levels.description: Comprehensive structural engineering analysis: diachronic function tracking, complete dependency graph, stress testing, adversarial attack simulation, full redundancy audit, and comparison of the author's perceived vs actual argumentative architecture

passes.description:
Exhaustive classification of every significant conceptual chain
with multi-layered function assessment. For each chain, determine
primary, secondary, and tertiary functions with detailed textual
evidence. Track diachronic function shifts: how has the chain's
argumentative role changed over the author's career? Assess
whether the author is aware of each chain's actual function.
Compare stated vs. actual argumentative roles. No chain is too
minor to classify -- peripheral chains often do unrecognized
structural work.
passes.label: Exhaustive Functional Classification

passes.description:
Build the complete dependency graph of the argumentative
architecture. Map every hierarchical relationship, bottleneck,
and structural logic pattern (linear, branching, converging,
cyclic). Perform comprehensive load-bearing analysis: rank all
load-bearing chains by structural importance, assess support
proportionality, identify single points of failure, compare
prominence with importance. Execute full redundancy audit:
complete overlap map with intentionality assessment for each
redundancy, resilience analysis, and historical redundancy
trajectory. Compare the author's explicit argument structure
with the implicit architecture revealed by functional analysis.
passes.label: Complete Architectural Engineering

passes.description:
Subject the entire argumentative architecture to adversarial
stress-testing. Simulate how a sophisticated interlocutor would
attack: which chains would they target, what objections would
they raise, where would the argument break? Map all weak points
with severity and exploitability ratings. Assess which defensive
chains are weakest relative to the objections they face. Identify
bridge concepts doing unacknowledged heavy lifting. Reflect on
whether some vulnerabilities are productive (enabling flexibility
and future development) vs. dangerous (threatening collapse under
scrutiny). Compare vulnerability patterns across the author's
career: are they getting better or worse at structural defense?
Produce recommendations for structural reinforcement.
passes.label: Adversarial Vulnerability Assessment

passes.description:
The confrontation pass identified vulnerabilities; now inhabit
them dialectically. The key question is not "how can these
weaknesses be fixed?" but "what do these structural tensions
PRODUCE?" An argument's vulnerabilities are not merely flaws
to be patched — they are often the sites of the argument's
greatest generative power.

For each significant structural tension, perform Aufhebung.
A load-bearing chain that lacks adequate support is vulnerable,
yes — but it may be load-bearing BECAUSE it is doing genuinely
novel work that existing argumentative resources cannot yet
support. The vulnerability is a symptom of intellectual
ambition outrunning available justification. Articulate what
each vulnerable chain is reaching for that the current
argumentative architecture cannot yet deliver.

Where redundancy exists, ask whether the multiplied chains
are genuinely saying the same thing or whether the apparent
redundancy conceals a dialectical development — each
"redundant" chain actually advancing the argument by
approaching the same conclusion from a different angle,
and the convergence of these different angles constituting
a stronger form of justification than any single chain could
provide. What looks like waste may be dialectical triangulation.

Where single-thread dependencies create fragility, do not
simply flag the risk. Trace WHY the author could not build
redundancy at that point. Often, single-thread dependencies
mark the places where the argument is most original — where
the author had to forge a new path with no existing support
structures to draw on. The fragility and the originality
are two faces of the same intellectual situation. Articulate
this relationship: where is fragility the price of ambition,
and where is it simply carelessness?

The overall question: does the argument's structural tension
create a productive instability that drives intellectual
development, or a destructive instability that threatens
collapse? Most arguments contain both kinds. Distinguish them.
passes.label: Dialectical Working-Through of Structural Tensions

depth_levels.suitable_for: Dense philosophical works, prolific authors, publication-grade structural analysis, comprehensive genealogy studies

key_concepts.definition: The inferential principle that licenses moving from data/grounds to claim, answering 'why does this evidence support this conclusion?' In Toulmin's model, warrants are the bridges that justify inferential steps. This engine identifies conceptual chains functioning as warrants—establishing the legitimacy of moves from one conceptual domain to another.
key_concepts.name: warrant

key_concepts.definition: The support structure underlying a warrant, establishing why the warrant itself is reliable or applicable in this context. The engine identifies conceptual chains that provide backing—not direct evidence for claims but meta-level justification for why certain inferential patterns or conceptual connections are trustworthy.
key_concepts.name: backing

key_concepts.definition: Modal indicators specifying the strength or scope of a claim ('presumably,' 'certainly,' 'in most cases'). The engine tracks how conceptual chains function as qualifiers—limiting, strengthening, or conditioning the applicability of other concepts rather than directly supporting conclusions.
key_concepts.name: qualifier

key_concepts.definition: Conditions or circumstances that would defeat, undermine, or limit a claim despite otherwise adequate warrant. The engine identifies defensive conceptual chains that anticipate objections and specify boundary conditions, revealing where authors perceive their arguments as vulnerable and requiring protection.
key_concepts.name: rebuttal

key_concepts.definition: Recurring patterns of inference with characteristic form and associated critical questions (argument from authority, analogy, consequence, sign, etc.). The engine classifies conceptual chains by scheme type, recognizing that chains performing similar argumentative functions may have different structural vulnerabilities depending on which inferential pattern they instantiate.
key_concepts.name: argumentation_scheme

key_concepts.definition: Conceptual chains or nodes that support extensive downstream reasoning, whose removal or weakness would compromise large portions of the argument. The engine identifies which conceptual developments carry the most structural weight—where failure would be catastrophic versus merely inconvenient—enabling assessment of argumentative resilience.
key_concepts.name: load_bearing_structure

key_concepts.definition: The specific structural role a conceptual chain plays in the overall argument: foundational (establishing premises), elaborative (developing implications), defensive (answering objections), bridge (connecting domains), or culminative (synthesizing conclusions). The engine's primary output is classification of each significant conceptual chain by function, revealing the argument's engineering blueprint.
key_concepts.name: argumentative_function

primary.description: Stephen Toulmin (1922-2009), British philosopher who revolutionized argumentation analysis by proposing that arguments have architectural structure beyond simple premises-and-conclusion. His model identifies six functional components (claim, data, warrant, backing, qualifier, rebuttal) that map how arguments actually work in practical reasoning, providing this engine with its foundational insight that conceptual chains perform distinct structural roles rather than merely accumulating evidence.
primary.name: toulmin

secondary.description: Chaïm Perelman (1912-1984), Belgian philosopher who developed the New Rhetoric by analyzing how arguments establish presence and adherence in audiences through strategic selection and amplification. His work on argumentative techniques and the architecture of persuasion complements Toulmin by showing how conceptual chains create hierarchies of importance—which ideas bear structural weight depends partly on rhetorical strategies that make certain concepts foundational and others derivative.
secondary.name: perelman

secondary.description: Douglas Walton (1942-2020), Canadian logician who systematized argumentation schemes—recurring patterns of inference used in practical reasoning, each with characteristic critical questions and vulnerabilities. His taxonomy of schemes enables this engine to classify conceptual chains not just by position (foundational, elaborative) but by inferential type, revealing where arguments rely on authority, analogy, consequence, or other specific patterns that carry different epistemic loads.
secondary.name: walton

secondary.description: Robert Brandom (1950-), American philosopher whose inferentialism treats concepts as nodes in networks of inferential commitments and entitlements. His analysis of how concepts gain content through their inferential role informs this engine's understanding that a concept's argumentative function—what work it does—is inseparable from its position in chains of reasoning, making the mapping of inferential architecture essential to understanding conceptual content itself.
secondary.name: brandom

traditions.description: An interdisciplinary field emerging in the mid-20th century that studies argument as structured social practice rather than formal logical validity, examining how claims are supported, challenged, and warranted in actual discourse. This tradition provides the engine with methodological tools for analyzing arguments as functional architectures where different elements perform specific work (establishing premises, connecting grounds to claims, defending against objections) rather than as linear chains of propositions.
traditions.name: argumentation_theory

traditions.description: A movement initiated by Perelman and Olbrechts-Tyteca (1958) recovering classical rhetorical analysis for philosophical argumentation, focusing on how arguments gain adherence through techniques of presence, association, and dissociation rather than formal proof. This tradition informs the engine's attention to how conceptual chains establish hierarchies—which concepts become foundational versus elaborative often reflects rhetorical strategies of emphasis and framing rather than purely logical necessity.
traditions.name: new_rhetoric

traditions.description: A field developed since the 1970s analyzing real-world arguments using standards appropriate to practical reasoning rather than formal deductive validity, emphasizing argument structure, fallacy identification, and context-sensitive evaluation. This tradition provides the engine with frameworks for identifying argumentative vulnerabilities—places where conceptual chains doing critical structural work rest on weak or insufficient support—and for distinguishing strong from weak warrants in non-formal reasoning.
traditions.name: informal_logic

traditions.description: A semantic program, particularly associated with Brandom and Sellars, holding that conceptual content is constituted by inferential role—what follows from applying a concept and what commitments license its application. This tradition grounds the engine's core methodology: understanding what argumentative work a concept does requires mapping its inferential connections, since a concept's function (foundational, elaborative, bridge) is determined by its position in networks of material inference.
traditions.name: inferentialism

traditions.description: An analytical approach examining how components of complex systems relate to form stable configurations, identifying load-bearing elements, redundancies, and points of potential failure. Adapted from engineering and structuralist thought, this tradition provides the engine with its central metaphor: conceptual systems have architecture where some chains bear argumentative weight, others provide redundancy, and weak points create vulnerability, making the system's structure as important as its content.
traditions.name: structural_analysis

problematique:
Not all concepts in a body of work do the same job. Some serve as
foundations -- they establish the premises on which everything else
rests. Others elaborate -- they develop implications, extend scope,
or fill in detail. Still others are defensive -- they anticipate
and respond to objections, shoring up vulnerabilities. Bridge
concepts connect domains that would otherwise remain separate,
enabling cross-pollination. And culminative concepts bring threads
together into conclusions, the endpoints of argumentative arcs.

This engine takes the evolution timelines and synthesis output from
concept_synthesis and asks: what ARGUMENTATIVE WORK does each
conceptual chain do? It classifies every significant chain into
one or more functional categories: foundational, elaborative,
defensive, bridge, or culminative. But it goes beyond mere
classification. It maps the ARGUMENTATIVE ARCHITECTURE -- how
chains compose into larger argumentative structures, which chains
bear the most structural load, where redundancy exists (multiple
chains doing the same argumentative work), and where the argument
is most vulnerable (chains doing critical work with weak support).

The key insight is Toulmin's: arguments are not just claims and
evidence but complex structures with warrants, backing, qualifiers,
and rebuttals. Each conceptual chain plays a specific role in this
